messageBody:
I agree with everything that everyone has said - namely that the business
logic should be outwith the MIDlet.
One thing that I don't understand is how to run unit tests against the KVM.
There are two ways of running tests:
1) write a test midlet that calls the tests and run on an emulator (or real
device).
2) Use the skeleton j2me unit framework and run in text mode.

My problem is that I don't know how to run the latter mode on the KVM - when
I try to run the tests I run into problems when I try to test elements
supported by the KVM.

As an example, say I have a MIDlet that just saves some arbitrary value in
persistent storage by calling a "Permanent Storage Manager" class. If I run
a test in the emulator (type 1 test above) then everything is hunky-dory but
if I run a test in text mode then a RecordStoreException is thrown
(presumably because the standard VM doesn't support the native functionality
required to create a Database).

So to summarise - how do I run tests which rely on the KVM (without running
up an emulator) on a desktop.

Any further help much appreciated.

Cheers,
Jeremy.

-----Original Message-----
From: don_quixada [mailto:xanthus@...]
Sent: 27 March 2002 23:36
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Re: j2me unit testing

--- In junit@y..., "Brian Button" <bbutton01@e...> wrote:
> The reason you use J2MEUnit is that it allows you to test your code
with the
> J2ME KVM. JUnit won't do that.

Is that all J2ME Unit does? test code with the KVM?

Because if it is, your statement makes me very curious about
something. We use Ant for compiling and testing etc whenever
possible. Ant has a JUnit optional-task
(http://jakarta.apache.org/ant/manual/index.html) and within that
task there is a choice of what JVM can be used. It defaults
with 'java'; however, it can easily be changed to 'kvm' (if the 'kvm'
standalone VM is installed on your machine-- which it is on mine).

So... it seems that there is really no need for J2ME Unit if one can
test using JUnit and the KVM.

Do you think that will work?

dq
